channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Big Dividends, Bigger Opportunity! Perl role with multiple location options
item.description: Our client is an online financial services company, still rapidly expanding after 20 years of impressive growth. With a truly international presence, they’re well known globally in their niche. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Perl in Vienna
item.description: Our client takes the legwork out of the hunt for the best bargain, offering one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: Cooking Up Something Good. Perl role in London
item.description: With a knack for tailoring content to a variety of site aesthetics, our client sets a banquet of advertising delights for over 349 million consumers around the world. If your mouth is watering at the thought of joining this dynamic team and you’re a senior Perl programmer with a solid understanding of Go programming languages, they just might set a place for you at the table.

item.title: A New Adventure is only a Click Away. Perl Developer role in London
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: US Based, Modern Perl Developer Role - 100% remote!
item.description: Our client is looking for a Perl programmer who wants to tame the job jungle for employers and employees through their candidate sourcing and data management products. The role is 100% remote within the United States.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud 2021
item.description: Online 9-11 June 2021.

item.description: Thursday, May 6, 2021

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: You Need Measurable Goals
item.description: Not really Perl specific, but still true.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 107
item.description: Simon's List Methods task solution is very cool. Please checkout yourself.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107: Self-Descriptive Methods
item.description: Roger made the Self-Descriptive numbers task so easy to follow and understand. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107: copying myself
item.description: Luca used Meta Object Class of Raku to solve the List Methods task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107
item.description: Luis presented us two versions of Self-Descriptive numbers task solutions. Cool interpretation.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107: Self-Descripting Numbers and List Methods
item.description: Laurent presented the complete solution for Self-descriptive numbers task, you don't want to miss out.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107
item.description: James becoming master of one-liners now. I really enjoyed his List Methods solution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 107
item.description: Jaldhar shared efficient Raku solution to the Self-Descriptive numbers task.

item.title: PWC107 - List Methods
item.description: Flavio fun story around the task is very creative. You don't want to miss it either.

item.title: PWC107 - Self-descriptive Numbers
item.description: Flavio curious to know the reason behind the weekly challenge. Well, the motto is to have fun and share knowledge. Thanks for your participation.

item.title: Self Description Redux: Perl Weekly Challenge 107
item.description: You don't want to miss the improverised version of Self-descriptive numbers task.

item.title: Self-Deceptive Methods with Raku
item.description: Arne shared something new about Self-Descriptive Numbers. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Static Analysis and Self Describing Numbers (now with Threads!): The Weekly Challenge 107
item.description: Adam used threads to solve the Self-descriptive numbers task. Very Cool.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107: List Methods
item.description: I loved Abigail explanation about BEGIN. There is always something new to learn from Abigail blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107: Self-descriptive Numbers
item.description: Abigail took the pain to explain the maths behind the Self-descriptive numbers task. It is not for kids.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 107
item.description: Aaron made the task looks simple with the power of Raku. Incredible.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 105
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 107
item.description: Enjoy quick recap of last week contributions by the Team PWC dealing with the "Self-descriptive Numbers" and "List Methods" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 108
item.description: Welcome new week with couple of fun tasks "Locate Memory" and "Bell Numbers". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Grant Proposals: March 2021
item.description: There were no grant proposals submitted for March, but TPF accepts grant proposals all year round.

item.title: Exploring BDD in Perl - using Test::BDD::Cucumber - part 5
Course Management Application in Mojolicious - par 2
Creating a Perl binding to a C library using FFI with Sawyer X
item.description: Next week

item.title: Moving from CGI to PSGI and Starman
item.description: A full example of a simple CGI script rewritten to be a PSGI script that can be deployed both as CGI - for backward compatibility, and using Starman. The aricle contains the Rexfile to deploy the whole thing including Apache on an Ubuntu based server.

item.title: Data visualization: Using amCharts with Perl and Mojo
Proxying web feeds with Dancer2
item.description: Dave has been working on a new version of his personal web site that makes him explore various web technologies.

item.title: Counter with Dancer using in-memory SQLite database
item.description: An example trying to show how to use in-memory SQLite database with Dancer. I wrote this in response to a query by someone, but I am not sure there is any good reason to do anything like this in a real application.

item.title: Perl One-liner: countdown on the command line
item.description: I think is the first time I created an animated gif recording my terminal. Nice.

item.title: Test code which is using fork
The attraction of Test::Fatal in Perl
Regression Testing Table Data with Spreadsheet::Compare
Release 1.53 of perl-workflow, a minor feature release
Releases of Perl Distributions Crypt::OpenSSL::PKCS12 and Crypt::OpenSSL::X509
Attribute::Handlers to wrap a function
item.description: Mark Gardner pointed to the around modifiers of Moo and Moose as simpler alternatives.

item.title: Readonly::Tiny
item.description: Readonly::Tiny is better than constant.

item.title: .env - the dot env application configuration file
Fatpacking fatpack
item.description: Fatpack makes it easy to create a single-file distribution from your perl-only application. So how can you distribute Fatpack itself as a Fatpack?

item.title: Tenjin templating system
item.description: One of my clients is using this module, so I thought I try it to see how it is being used.

item.title: Sawyer is stepping down from PSC and Core
#507 - Live events
item.description:
Hi there!

Sorry for sending out this edition later than usual, I have been super busy with various video recordings. Primarily the live events I have been doing lately. I think they work quite well.

I am also glad that there are a number of Perl Monger meetings you can attend on-line. It is just a matter of allocating the time.

Because I am late with the newsletter the email from Sawyer X in which he writes about his resignation from PSC and Core found its way to my inbox and not to the newsletter as well. Surprising.

Well, Enjoy your week!
